Award.AwardTitle: Tuyuryaq (Togiak, Alaska): A Model for Alaska Native Youth Learning on College Campuses
Award.AbstractNarration:
Paragraph 1:
This award supports Alaska Native students attendance at a workshop at Bates College focused on investigating new models for advancing academic achievement by Indigenous students on college campuses. As a Yup'ik scientist, PI Dr. Kristen Barnett, understands first-hand how college campuses are critical environments for providing Indigenous students with a pathway to science careers, yet Alaska Native youth have limited participation and face limited support at institutions of higher learning. Barnett points out that scientific research frequently focuses on topics that directly affect Indigenous communities, e.g., coastal erosion, permafrost, fisheries, the digital economy, and could benefit by incorporating Indigenous experiences and epistemologies into the science curricula at academic institutions. The vision for this workshop, Tuyyuryaq (Togiak, Alaska), is to develop new models for improving the learning environment for Indigenous students on college campuses, as well as ways in which faculty can reenvision academic institutions and the ways in which they impart knowledge to Indigenous students and communities. Creating opportunities for Alaska Native and Native American students is strongly in the national interest; these groups are highly underrepresented in higher education and in science disciplines in particular. Increasing the participation of these groups can provide leadership and economic opportunity in regions of the U.S. where opportunities for development are currently limited.

Paragraph 2:
This workshop seeks to overcome structural inequalities in higher education and for indigenous students in particular, by developing and applying inclusive epistemologies derived from multiple cultures. The workshop provides a platform for collaborative participation accommodating a wide range of Indigenous communities, interdisciplinary scholars, students, administration and staff, and the general public. The workshop will consists of an opening plenary session, followed by multiple small group sessions that facilitate immersive and sensitive discussions among participants, and concludes with a larger group discussion that highlights conference experiences, ideas and future directions. Participants will access tools for curriculum development and deepen their understanding of impacts of the current (western) educational models. The long-term goals of this workshop is to advance awareness and support the incorporation of inclusive practices of research and teaching, to encourge student involvement in campus culture that is scalable to any institution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The workshop, Tuyuryaq: a model for Alaska Native Youth Learning on College Campuses, took place at Bates College, Lewiston, Maine over the course of three days, October 24, 25 & 26, 2018. Six Indigenous scholars from an interdisciplinary range of backgrounds presented their work and conducted hands-on workshops made available to students, faculty, administrators, and staff. 

Maggie Walter (Palawa), University of Tasmania, provided an impactful keynote address that braoched topics of settler-colonialism; western research design, specifically deficit models; and Indigenous statistic models for high-impact equitable research practice. Individual 2-hour workshops included Maggie Walter (Palawa) Indigneous quantatative methodologies; Theresa Jean Ambo (Gabrieliño/Tongva and Tohono O'odham) Decolonizing Institutional Relationships; Maulian Dana (Penobscot), Visibility and Reclaiming Identity; Melissa Watkinson (Chickasaw), Stewards of Environmenal Justice through Indigenous Scholarship; Darren Ranco (Penobscot), Decolonizing the Academy through Heritage Protection Agreements; and Annita Lucchesi (Southern Cheyenne) Cartography as Indigenous Learning Practice.

There were more than 100 attendees from across the globe, many from the North East United States and Bates College, in addition to attendees from Alaska, Canada, Australia and the Western United States. Of the attendees, more than 20% (N=24) were Indigneous/First Nations/Native, 5 of whom were highschool students or freshmen in college.

The final day concluded with a discussion led by 4 panelists: Chelsea Blackmore PhD, Anthropology at UC Santa Cruz; April Hill PhD, Biology at Bates College; Patrick Otim PhD, History at Bates College; and Sonja Thomas PhD, Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies at Colby College.

The impacts of this workshop are ongoing. Bates College has continued to express interest in the pursue decolonzing academia and has requested a 3 part faculty, staff and administration facing programming this Fall 2019. The instituion hired 2 additional Indigenous/First nations/Native faculty, bringing the curretn total to 3; a number that begins to address stabilty for these individual potential for success on our campus. In addition, Bates has reflected on, and begun revision of policies and relationships, including those with local native communities to engage in collaboration and partnership on land acknowledgement. Future work on decolonizing will include trustee facing work. Individual faculty participants were transformed in the way they develop syllabi and produce knowledge including restructuring of research design and developing data sovereignty, and TK labels. Faculty are still grapppling with how to follow through with this work and have continued to engage in literature, dialogue, and programming.

2 Alaska Native students and their chaperone Helen Gregorio, a member of the Togiak School Board and Tribal Courts, visited campus in a broader capacity as well as attended the workshop.  Workshop attendance and their time at Bates College has impacted them as well as their peers in Togiak. For the students, it was their first time outside of Alaska, and their first introduction to higher education. The students were paired with Bates peers they knew from earlier collaborative research in Togiak, Ak. During thier visit they were introduced to campus activites (e.g. dining hall, classrooms, sports activities including volleyball and basketball) in addition to the workshop attendance. They were also invited to off-campus activites with Bates peers, now considered friends, and attended a movie at the theater, picked apples, shopped at the mall, visited lighthouses, and went to a haunted house. These experiences my seem mundane but these students come from a rural village of 800 poeple completely off the road system in Bristol Bay, Alaska.  The village has one small store and functions as a 95% subsistence economy. The current outcomes for highschool graduates in Togiak is the same as those that drop out, or do not attend school. This experience has helped shift these outcomes. Since the workshop, one of the student returned to Bates to complete an internship along with another Togiak student, and has since begun the college application process. A high number number (5) of graduating students in Togiak this year (2019) are seeking out opportunity for education and training beyond highschool, developing community capacity for self determination and exercising sovereign rights. Demystifying college, providing Indigneous/Native/First Nations leadership and mentorship, and developing decolonizing practices on college campuses will continue to have longlasting impacts, increasing accessibility and opportunity for native youth.
